captions.text:
Nicole Sweeney: Deadly yogurt geiser.
Stefan Chin: Set your phasers to moist.

Sarah Gullickson: Incarcerated toothbrushes.
Timothy Thomas: Smile like a donut.

Caitlin Hofmeister: Microsoft fingernail simulator.
Megan Toenyes: I'm proud of my sand.

Travis Morss: Butter flavored tree gas.
Nicole Sweeney: Long bee squeeze fight. (Laugh)

Hailey Faust: Molten dog hair.
Lou Winkler: We swam the way giraffes eat

wallpaper.
Michael Aranda: I wanted to sample some spicy

guitar, but I couldn't fit the napkin 'round
it.
Sarah Meismer: Tentacled popcorn.

Hank: There are a lot of different ways to
not make any sense at all, but of all of them,

the fact that some people don't have access
to simple healthcare despite the fact that

we live at the peak moment of wealth in human
history makes the least sense of all.

Partners in Health is dedicated to ending
that weird, lopsided world. They empower and

equip local health workers and have been working
with the people on the front lines of the

fight against ebola before any of us in the
US even knew that there was an outbreak.

Ebola is a world health problem. Antibiotic
resistance is a world health problem. Pneumonia

is a world health problem. No community is
exempt from these challenges, and Partners

in Health is doing genuinely heroic work around
the world to save lives, not just now, but

a hundred years from now.
Partners in Health is a huge part of the ongoing

success story of increased access to healthcare
and decreased suffering throughout the world,

and through our support, we will also be a
part of that success story.

For the first half of the Project for Awesome,
we'll be splitting the money raised between

Partners in Health and an equally amazing
organization, Save the Children. We'll also

have matching funds for the first 500,000
dollars donated, meaning that if we reach

500,00 dollars by noon on Saturday, a total
of a million dollars will be given to partners

in health and Save the Children.
During the second half, the money raised will

be distributed via your votes. To watch videos
promoting charities and vote on the ones that

capture your interest and attention, head
to projectforawesome.com. Together, through

the Project for awesome, we're gonna help
the world make a little bit more sense.

Good morning John! This was my Project for
Awesome video, I'm looking forward to seeing

everybody else's.
So in addition to making videos, watching

videos, voting on charities at projectforawesome.com
we also have the fundraising element. That

takes place over an indiegogo, and it's just
a way to donate to charity, but, in addition

to donating to charity and making the world
a less nonsensical place, you'll also get

stuff! Stuff that you can't get any other
way!

Things like the reproduction of the prop version
of An Imperial Affliction, with seven pages

repeated over and over again, written by John
Green, the author of The Fault in Our Stars

and also my brother and also the guy who runs
this video blog with me.

It's an exact replica of the one that Shailene
Woodley reads in the movie. We also have the

special edition of The Fault in Our Stars,
only available through the Project for Awesome

-- it's green.
Let's see what else. We've got a calendar,

every year we've got a calendar, but this
year the calendar is baby pictures of YouTubers,

including... this guy. So. It's cute.
We got a penny squashing machine, we're squashing

pennies and stamping Project for Awesome and
nerdfighteria logos on 'em. Death to pennies.

We've also got a couple hundred of these,
hanklerfish arts, yeah, been doing that while

watching Gilmore Girls. Every one of these
is a beautiful moment between a loving mother

and her wonderful daughter.
Katherine and I are doing a full movie commentary

of the Princess Bride, because we love that
movie. We've got compilations of nerdfighter

music and amazing nerdfighter art that's just...
better than ever; just keeps getting more

awesome every year.
And we'll be adding a ton of Project for Awesome

perks during the 48-hour livestream; can't
spoil all of the surprises now. And during

that livestream, if previous years are any
indication, we will get a little bit silly

and amazing things will happen and we will
be joined by lots of your favorite YouTubers

or at least my favorite YouTubers, and it's
gonna be great.

The livestream will be running from Friday,
that's today, at noon, all the way to Sunday,

at noon. That's Eastern Time noon, not any
other noons.

And now it's time to take it back down again
for the outtro.

Thanks for everybody who helped out here at
the office and thanks to all of you for participating

in the Project for Awesome, whether you're
giving or making videos or hanging out on

the livestream or all of those things. Our
goal here this weekend is just to help the

world make a little bit more sense.
John, I'll see you in the livestream.

comments.author: AngelsHaveThePhonebox

comments.text:
Hank, I'm afraid that most of us are seen as just so much " surplus 
population '' by most of the wealthy in the world. Here in the U.P.S.A ( 
United Police States of America ), the police can't seem to shoot us fast 
enough to suit some . Our elected officials seem to either think that 
health care should only be had by the highest bidder, or worst, that it's 
not worth really fighting for ( they could be putting there jobs in danger 
). And without a doubt, at least to me, is the wholesale abandonment of 
news reporting. Our news media has been completely taken over ( bought and 
paid for ) by the same groups that put most of us in that " surplus 
population " category. Now they have their eyes on Youtube, and when that's 
taken I see no place left for real " News that you can use".  Hank, sorry 
for the bummer comment, but at least we have the Green brothers on our 
side. As that other Don Q said ( in the movie anyway ) " It's a Knights 
duty, nay, his honor to be on the quest. That quest for an impossible 
dream.       ﻿

comments.text:
John and Hank, Thank you so much for supporting Partners In Health. I have 
been an active supporter of the organization for the past few years, 
working alongside Partners In Health to create a nationwide student 
movement here in Canada. I'm also a long-time follower of the vlogbrothers; 
and it's simply wonderful to see two things that I am passionate about come 
together in such a positive way. 

I believe in health as a human right. 
And I'm glad people like you are spreading the word.

Omar﻿

comments.text:
This was a great video for Partners in Health! I've said it before and I'll 
say it again-- THANK YOU SO MUCH for having them as one of the charities! 
These guys have been one of my absolute top favorite charities for 10 
years--like, it's them, charity: water and Best Friends Animal Sanctuary at 
the top and that's it, nothing else competes with how much I especially 
love those three organizations. So I was SO happy when you announced they'd 
be one of them--not only for them getting money during P4A but also for 
spreading the word about them to people who might not have heard yet. I 
already donated but who knows, I might donate again and again to give them 
even more lol﻿

comments.author: Hannah Jones

comments.text:
Oh my goodness, thank you SO MUCH Hank for making a video on Partners in 
Health and choosing this for your P4A. I'm a highschool senior and we 
started PIH as a club in our highschool 2 years ago and we have been 
fundraising for charity and also educating people about global health 
through our own projects. However, it's always a little difficult because 
not many people know about Partners in Health, at least where I'm from, and 
the general public is always hesistant to put their trust in donating 
towards Partners in Health. But now that PIH is going a little more 
mainstream (Paul Farmer was recently on Colbert Report!!!), people are 
starting to become more aware of what Partners in Health is all about. So 
again, thank you for the wonderful awesomeness for the stuff that you do 
and yeah :)﻿
comments.author: Khansa Mahum

comments.text:
Oh my god, we read Mountains Beyond Mountains as a summer project for my 
economics class (lolz I have no idea why because the teacher never even 
asked us about it and was confused when we asked him if there was going to 
be a test on it) but regardless, yes I do love the book very much, totally 
made me appreciate Paul Farmer as a person. Thats how our PIH group 
actually started. And 10 years, omg you're a committed member! But I'm glad 
I got to connect with someone else associated with PIH because there is 
hardly any activity associated with it where I'm from (upstate newyork). 
The only time you hear something is if you go to the Boston training thing.
comments.author: Khansa Mahum

comments.text:
That's so awesome! I absolutely LOVE Partners in Health too--I've loved 
them for 10 years (I learned about them in college in a medical 
anthropology class when they had us read Mountains Beyond Mountains, which 
I'm assuming you've already read but if you haven't omg go do it now). I'm 
so glad to hear you guys have a club to spread the word about them :) ALSO 
WHAT?? PAUL FARMER WAS ON THE COLBERT REPORT??? I didn't know that! I'm 
going to go look for that now! Thank you!

comments.author: KatyAndTheKats

comments.text:
Voting on the videos is giving a lot! Even if you can't afford to give any 
money at all, if you vote on the videos you like best, you will help ensure 
that those charities are more likely to get money. Trust me, the charities 
will really, really, really thank you for that single vote if they end up 
being chosen. Then, you'll be helping to ensure that the money other people 
can afford to donate is funneled in part to that charity. So don't feel 
like you aren't helping or you're just being idle--seriously, you clicking 
those vote buttons does a whole lot :)
